"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Congress finds that the political relationship between the United States Territory of American Samoa and the United States is based on two treaties of cessions signed in 1900 and 1904. The Act of February 20, 1929 ratified these treaties, granting civil, judicial, and military powers to be vested in individuals directed by the President until Congress provides for the government of the islands. President Truman transferred the administration of American Samoa from the Secretary of the Navy to the Secretary of the Interior in 1951. Congress authorizes additional jurisdiction for the High Court of American Samoa under the Act of February 20, 1929. The High Court of American Samoa has federal jurisdiction and administrative duties. The High Court of American Samoa has jurisdiction over criminal cases under US law in American Samoa. Appeals can be made to the Appellate Division of the High Court and then to the US District Court for the District of Hawaii. The Chief Justice of the High Court of American Samoa administers all matters related to the justices, judges, clerks, and administrative staff. The Secretary of the Interior appoints additional justices as needed, considering their legal training and knowledge. The Secretary of the Interior appoints a special prosecutor for American Samoa to prosecute criminal violations of US laws under the jurisdiction of the High Court, considering their legal training and knowledge of traditional laws. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DATE; NEEDS ASSESSMENT.

This Act will take effect after 120 days from enactment. The Secretary of the Interior and the Attorney General, along with other officials, will assess staffing and administrative costs within 90 days.

SEC. 4. REPORT TO CONGRESS.

Within a year of enactment, the Secretary of the Interior will submit a report to Congress on the Act's implementation.

SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the Secretary of the Interior to implement the Act.
